newsitem.title: PANAMA: Ecuador's president backs Panama anti-drug center.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador's president backs Panama anti-drug center.

text.p: Ecuador's President Abdala Bucaram on Saturday backed a proposal to turn a U.S. military base in Panama into an international drug interdiction centre.
"We're going to support this centre," Bucaram told a news conference during a three-day visit to Panama.

Bucaram said he would meet on Sunday with General Wesley Clark, the commander-in-chief of the United States Southern Command military forces based in Panama, to discuss the anti-drug project before returning to Ecuador.

"It's obvious that the United States has a responsibility to participate. They're one of the major causes of the drug trafficking problem because 75 percent of the world's drugs are consumed there," he said.
Panamanian President Ernesto Perez Balladares has said the United States can keep strategic Howard Air Force Base in Panama at no cost for use as an international centre to fight drug trafficking.
Under bilateral canal treaties, the United States is to turn over control of the Panama Canal and withdraw all troops and bases by Dec. 31, 1999.
